questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Arenaviruses and bunyaviruses are enveloped RNA viruses with a segmented circular, single-stranded genome, and helical capsid shape. They are responsible for a variety of acute febrile illnesses such as Lassa fever and Hantavirus syndromes that manifest with cutaneous symptoms, including rash. However, neither arenaviruses nor bunyaviruses would cause superficial, flesh-colored, hyperkeratotic papules in an otherwise healthy pediatric patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Orthomyxoviruses, paramyxoviruses, rhabdoviruses, filoviruses, and coronaviruses are all enveloped RNA viruses with a linear, single-stranded genome and helical capsid shape. Cutaneous manifestations of viruses in these families include the erythematous maculopapular rashes caused by the measles virus (a paramyxovirus) and hemorrhagic fever caused by the Ebola and Marburg viruses (filoviruses). However, none of these viruses would cause superficial, flesh-colored, hyperkeratotic papules in an otherwise healthy pediatric patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Poxviruses are enveloped DNA viruses with a linear, double-stranded genome and complex capsid shape. Molluscum contagiosum is caused by a poxvirus. It is most frequently seen in children and presents with flesh-colored papules, as seen here. However, the lesions of molluscum contagiosum are pearly, dome-shaped and have a central umbilication, unlike the lesions described in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpesviruses are enveloped DNA viruses with a linear, double-stranded genome and icosahedral capsid shape. They are a large family of viruses that cause a variety of pathologies, the most pertinent in this 13-year-old boy with skin lesions on his fingers being HSV-1/HSV-2 (herpetic whitlow) and VZV (herpes zoster). However, herpetic skin lesions manifest with grouped, painful vesicles on an erythematous base, whereas this patient has flesh-colored, hyperkeratotic papules without surrounding erythema.

E) CORRECT:

HPV is a nonenveloped DNA virus with a circular, double-stranded genome and icosahedral capsid shape. Certain serotypes of HPV (particularly 1, 2, and 4) are the cause of common warts, which appear as skin-colored, scaly papules (sometimes with a cauliflower-like appearance) on the elbows, knees, fingers, and/or palms. This type of wart is most common in childhood and adolescence. Common warts are transmitted via close person-to-person contact, but other serotypes of HPV are sexually transmitted and can cause a variety of pathologies, including benign anogenital warts (serotypes 6 and 11) and cervical cancer (serotypes 16 and 18).
Image Description:

Multiple whitish plaques and papules are visible on the distal end of the fingers. A larger hyperkeratotic plaque with a verrucous and scaly surface can be seen on the distal end of the right thumb.

Common warts are typically associated with HPV infection.

F) INCORRECT:

Picornaviruses, hepeviruses, and caliciviruses are nonenveloped RNA viruses with a linear, single-stranded genome and icosahedral capsid shape. Picornaviruses include the Coxsackie A virus, which can manifest cutaneously in both herpangina and hand, foot, and mouth disease. Herpangina manifests with multiple, small vesicles on the posterior oropharynx. Hand, foot, and mouth disease manifests with oral ulcers and a maculopapular rash on the hands and feet. However, neither condition would cause superficial, flesh-colored, hyperkeratotic papules in an otherwise healthy pediatric patient.
questions.hint: This patient's physical examination findings suggest common warts, which are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV).

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician for an annual pelvic examination and Pap smear. Her last Pap smear was 3 years ago. She has been sexually active with multiple male partners and takes an oral contraceptive. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years. Pelvic examination shows no abnormalities. A photomicrograph of cervical cells from the Pap smear specimen is shown. Cells similar to the one indicated by the arrow are most likely to be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Genital herpes is commonly caused by HSV-2 and presents with redness, swelling, tingling, pain, and pruritus of the genitals. Histopathology of herpes virus infection reveals acantholysis and blister cavities, which contain keratinocytes showing features of viral infection (e.g. multinucleation and nuclear inclusions), rather than koilocytes as seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Trichomoniasis is caused by infection with Trichomonas vaginalis and presents with symptoms of vulvovaginitis and a foul-smelling, foamy, yellow-green, purulent vaginal discharge. Saline wet mount preparation shows motile flagellated protozoa rather than koilocytes, as seen here.
Image Description:

Phase contrast photomicrograph of vaginal discharge (high magnification)

These parasites with flagella (blue overlay) are Trichomonas vaginalis, the causative pathogen of trichomonal vaginitis.

In the center, two squamous epithelial cells can be seen.

C) CORRECT:

Koilocytes are pathognomonic of infection with human papillomavirus (HPV). Condylomata acuminata, like cervical dysplasia, are caused by an infection with HPV and can therefore present with koilocytes on histopathology. Condylomata acuminata are typically associated with HPV strains 6 and 11. Other manifestations of HPV infection include vulvar and vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia, as well as skin warts (verruca vulgaris) and plantar warts.

As this patient's Pap smear is consistent with a low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion, the next step in management includes testing for high-risk HPV strains (i.e., 16, 18, 31, and 33) via PCR. Depending on the result, this should be followed by colposcopy (positive high-risk HPV status) or repeated cytologic examination (negative high-risk HPV status).
Image Description:

Multiple exophytic, cauliflower-like, confluent, erythematous lesions are visible in the perianal region.

D) INCORRECT:

A (painless) genital chancre is seen in primary syphilis, which is caused by infection with Treponema pallidum. Dark-field microscopy of these lesions therefore shows treponemes without any specific cellular changes rather than koilocytes, as in this patient's histopathology.

E) INCORRECT:

Vulvovaginal candidiasis is caused by infection with Candida spp. and presents with symptoms of vulvovaginitis and a white lumpy, curd-like discharge. Wet mount preparation with potassium hydroxide (KOH) shows pseudohyphae with budding yeast rather than koilocytes, as seen here.

F) INCORRECT:

Bacterial vaginosis is caused by Gardnerella vaginalis and presents with increased, sometimes gray-colored vaginal discharge and a characteristically fishy odor. Wet mount preparation reveals presence of clue cells rather than koilocytes, as seen in this patient's photomicrograph.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a vaginal smear specimen (vaginal wet mount; medium power magnification)

Squamous cells with a stippled appearance and fuzzy borders can be seen (clue cells) due to bacteria adhering to the cell surface.

The presence of clue cells is one of the four Amsel criteria (besides thin, white, yellow, homogeneous discharge; vaginal fluid pH of > 4.5; and a fishy odor after adding 10% potassium hydroxide solution to wet mount) for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Gardnerella vaginalis is the most common cause of this condition.
questions.hint: The cell indicated by the arrow is a dysplastic squamous epithelial cell with a perinuclear halo, an enlarged, irregular nucleus, and hyperchromasia. These are features of koilocytes. If left untreated, these cells can progress to eventually cause cervical cancer.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician for a scheduled colposcopy. Two weeks ago, she had a routine Pap smear that showed atypical squamous cells. Colposcopy shows an area of white discoloration of the cervix with application of acetic acid solution. Biopsy of this area shows carcinoma-in-situ. Activation of which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phosphoprotein p24, which is a component of the HIV virus, is not related to HPV infection or the pathogenesis of cervical dysplasia as seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Mutations of the JAK-2 gene are seen in polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, and other chronic myeloproliferative disorders. Although these mutations cause deregulation of cell growth and division, they are not associated with the cervical dysplasia seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

E2F transcription factors that promote G1 to the S phase transition are normally inhibited by the retinoblastoma protein (pRb). High-risk types of HPV induce production of the oncoprotein E7, which binds and inactivates pRb, thereby increasing G1 to S phase transition and cell proliferation. High-risk HPV also induces the production of the oncoprotein E6, which binds and inactivates the tumor suppressor protein p53.

D) INCORRECT:

The p53 protein is a key tumor suppressor. Therefore, activation of the p53 protein would inhibit rather than promote tumor growth. Oncogenic HPV DNA induces the expression of the E6 protein, which binds and inactivates p53.

E) INCORRECT:

Cyclin-dependent kinases (CDK) are responsible for progression of the cell cycle. Therefore, activation of CDK inhibitors would arrest the cell cycle and prevent rather than promote tumor growth. Oncogenic HPV DNA induces the expression of E7 protein, which binds and inactivates the CDK inhibitors p21 and p27.
questions.hint: High-risk human papillomavirus subtypes, e.g., HPV 16 and HPV 18, are responsible for the majority of cervical cancers. These pathogens facilitate the transcription of proteins that alter tumor suppression upon successful infection of cervical cells.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a growth on his penis that has been gradually increasing in size over the past year. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 10 years ago. He has been divorced for 25 years and has had “at least 30 sexual partners” since. Physical examination shows a nontender 2.5-cm ulcerated lesion with an erythematous base on the dorsum of the glans. There is firm left inguinal lymphadenopathy. A biopsy of the lesion shows atypical squamous cells with varying degrees of mitotic activity. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following pathogens?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, particularly with types 16 and 18, is a known risk factor for carcinoma of the penis. Other risk factors for carcinoma of the penis include phimosis and HIV infection. Although HIV may directly contribute to carcinogenesis, this association may also be due to the frequent HPV co-infection in this patient group. Apart from the immunosuppression enabling the persistence of HPV infection, HIV also seems to directly promote HPV-associated carcinogenesis.

High-risk types of HPV (i.e., 16, 18, 31, 33) are also associated with cervical cancer (almost all cases), as well as anal, oral, and oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

B) INCORRECT:

EBV is associated with several malignancies such as Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, and gastric adenocarcinoma. However, EBV is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

C) INCORRECT:

HSV-2 is a sexually transmitted pathogen that causes genital herpes. Unlike this patient's slowly increasing painless ulcer, genital herpes typically manifests with multiple painful lesions that evolve from vesicles and pustules to ulcers over about 10 days. Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy is common. HSV-2 is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.
Image Description:

Penile shaft and glans

Two ulcerated blisters with erythematous margins are visible proximal to the corona of the glans.

D) INCORRECT:

H. ducreyi is a sexually transmitted pathogen that causes chancroid. Unlike this patient's presentation, chancroid typically manifests with erythematous papules that become pustular and erode into very painful genital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy. H. ducreyi is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

E) INCORRECT:

N. gonorrhoeae is a sexually transmitted pathogen and a common cause of genitourinary infections such as urethritis and epididymitis. None of these infections would cause a gradually increasing ulcerated lesion on the penis. Moreover, they are associated with symptoms such as purulent urethral discharge and dysuria (if urethritis), or scrotal pain and swelling (if epididymitis). N. gonorrhoeae is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

F) INCORRECT:

T. pallidum is a sexually transmitted pathogen that causes syphilis. Primary syphilis typically manifests with a solitary, painless ulcer in the genital region (chancre) as well as regional nontender lymphadenopathy. However, the ulcer does not increase gradually but typically heals spontaneously within 3–6 weeks. Systemic symptoms due to secondary syphilis are expected 3–4 months after primary infection. T. pallidum is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

G) INCORRECT:

C. trachomatis is a sexually transmitted pathogen whose serotypes L1–L3 can cause lymphogranuloma venereum. This condition initially manifests with a small, painless ulcer in the genital region. However, the ulcer does not increase gradually but typically heals and disappears within one week. After 2–6 weeks, the extension of the infection to the draining lymph nodes results in painful, suppurative, bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy accompanied by systemic symptoms (e.g., fever). C. trachomatis is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has carcinoma of the penis.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man with HIV comes to the physician because of rectal bleeding and itching for 2 weeks. During this period, he has also had pain with defecation. Four months ago, he was diagnosed with anogenital warts that were treated with cryotherapy. Over the past year, he has been sexually active with 3 male partners. He uses condoms inconsistently. Current medications are zidovudine, emtricitabine, and efavirenz. Digital rectal examination and anoscopy show an exophytic mass on the anal margin that is protruding into the anal canal. The mass is tender to palpation and bleeds easily on contact. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 7,600/mm3 and a CD4+ T-lymphocyte count of 410/mm3. A biopsy specimen of the lesion shows a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following cellular processes was most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's malignancy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Activation of the c-myc proto-oncogene is associated with infection with Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV), an oncogenic virus that can cause endemic Burkitt lymphoma. c-myc codes for a transcription factor that, when overexpressed, leads to unregulated cell proliferation and differentiation. In most cases of Burkitt lymphoma, the overactivation of c-myc is due to the translocation t(8;14). However, the c-myc gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with HPV-16 and HPV-18.

B) INCORRECT:

Inactivation of the von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) tumor suppressor gene due to a loss-of-function mutation can lead to von Hippel-Lindau disease. VHL is a protein involved in the degradation of hypoxia-inducible factor 1a (HIF-1). Deletion of VHL results in increased activity of HIF-1, which induces the transcription of target genes involved in the response to hypoxia (e.g., EPO and VEGF). VHL disease causes hemangioblastomas, bilateral renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytoma; however, it is not associated with anal squamous cell carcinoma. Moreover, the VHL gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with HPV-16 and HPV-18.

C) INCORRECT:

Activation of the TAX proto-oncogene is associated with infection with human T-lymphotropic virus type I (HTLV-I), an oncogenic virus that can cause adult T-cell leukemia (ATL). Once a CD4+ T-cell is infected by HTLV-I, TAX induces overexpression of stimulatory host transcription factors (e.g., NF-kB), which leads to uncontrolled T-cell proliferation. However, the TAX gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with HPV-16 and HPV-18.

D) INCORRECT:

Inactivation of Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) gene, a tumor suppressor gene that encodes for a transcription factor responsible for urogenital development, is caused by a loss-of-function mutation and can lead to malignancy (e.g., nephroblastoma) or genomic syndromes (e.g., Denys-Drash syndrome, WAGR syndrome). However, it is not associated with anal squamous cell carcinoma. Moreover, the WT1 gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with HPV-16 and HPV-18.

E) INCORRECT:

Activation of the KRAS gene, a proto-oncogene that encodes for a GTPase involved in the regulation of cell growth, is caused by a point mutation and has been implicated in the development of several cancers, including pancreatic adenocarcinoma, non-small cell lung cancer, and colorectal cancer. However, it is not associated with anal squamous cell carcinoma. Moreover, the KRAS gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with HPV-16 and HPV-18.

F) CORRECT:

Inactivation of the tumor suppressor proteins p53 and retinoblastoma protein (pRb) is implicated in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with the oncogenic viruses HPV-16 and HPV-18. HPV-16 produces oncoprotein E6, which inhibits p53. Oncoprotein E7 is produced by HPV-18 and inhibits pRb. Inactivation of these proteins leads to the continued growth and proliferation of damaged cells. General risk factors for the development of anal cancer include immunocompromised status (e.g., HIV), receptive anal intercourse, and infection with HPV (e.g., anogenital warts). HPV-16 and HPV-18 are also involved in the development of cervical, oral, and oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

Kaposi sarcoma, a malignancy strongly associated with HIV, is also caused by an oncogenic virus, HHV-8. This herpesvirus infects human endothelial cells and transforms them into neoplastic spindle cells via various oncogenic products that affect cell cycle regulation and apoptosis.
questions.hint: Infection with oncogenic human papillomavirus (HPV) strains likely played a role in the development of this patient's anal cancer.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of pain with defecation, anal itching, and blood in the stool. Over the past month, she has also had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss. She has a history of irritable bowel syndrome, HIV infection, and human papillomavirus infection. Current medications include a combined antiretroviral treatment regimen and an oral contraceptive. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is sexually active with one male partner. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 66/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg. Examination of the perianal region shows no abnormalities. Digital rectal examination shows a tender mass and bright red blood in the anal canal. Anoscopy shows an exophytic, ulcerated, 2.5-cm mass that is located just above the anocutaneous line and below the dentate line. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A fibroepithelial polyp of the anus can manifest as an exophytic lesion in the perianal region. However, patients are usually asymptomatic. Moreover, fibroepithelial polyps of the anus arise from anal columns at the dentate line rather than near the anocutaneous line.

B) INCORRECT:

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) of the anus manifests as an exophytic, bleeding perianal mass. Besides being very rare (the main risk factor for BCC is sun exposure), BCC of the anus arises below rather than above the anocutaneous line. Moreover, although this condition is associated with immunodeficiency (e.g., caused by HIV infection), it is not associated with HPV infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Internal hemorrhoids can manifest with anal pruritus, hematochezia, and a palpable mass on digital rectal examination. Furthermore, in a patient with irritable bowel syndrome, constipation is a common feature and a risk factor for developing hemorrhoids. However, internal hemorrhoids more commonly appear as dilated, purple or blue veins on anoscopy rather than an exophytic ulcerated mass, and, because they arise from the superior hemorrhoidal plexus, they are located above the dentate line rather than the anocutaneous line. Moreover, defecation is usually painless and weight loss is not expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Condylomata acuminata of the anus is caused by HPV infection, which this patient has a history of, and can manifest as an exophytic lesion. However, although condylomata acuminata are pruritic, tender, and friable in a small percentage of cases, they are more commonly asymptomatic; weight loss is not expected. Moreover, when present in the anal canal, condylomata acuminata usually appear as small papules rather than large, ulcerated lesions.

E) INCORRECT:

Paget disease of the anus can manifest with anal pruritus, pain with defecation, and hematochezia, all of which are seen here. However, besides being extremely rare, this condition usually manifests as well-demarcated erythematous plaques or patches with a white scale rather than a single ulcerated, exophytic lesion.

F) CORRECT:

A history of hematochezia, anal pruritus, painful defecation, and weight loss in a patient with an exophytic, friable, ulcerated mass above the anal verge is suggestive of anal canal cancer. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common histological type of anal canal cancer and typically arises below the dentate line (see “Characteristics of the anal canal above and below the dentate line” table). Patients must undergo a biopsy of the tumor to confirm the diagnosis. Women diagnosed with anal canal squamous cell carcinoma should also undergo a gynecological examination for cervical cancer screening.
questions.hint: A history of immunodeficiency (e.g., caused by HIV infection) and prior human papillomavirus (HPV) infection are major risk factors for this condition.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of multiple painless bumps on the vulva. The bumps are mildly itchy; one of the bumps has bled before when she tried to pull on it. She does not have urinary symptoms or changes in bowel movements. She denies dyspareunia. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Last year, she was treated for a chlamydia infection. She does not smoke cigarettes but occasionally smokes marijuana. She works for a financial startup. Her only medication is an over-the-counter vitamin supplement. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the genital area is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An HIV test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum (MC) is a localized infection of the skin caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus. MC most commonly affects young children but can manifest in adults with nontender lesions in the genital region. However, the lesions of MC are typically discrete, pearly, dome-shaped, and smooth, with central umbilication; MC does not cause exophytic and cauliflower-like masses. Although large, widespread lesions can develop in individuals who are immunocompromised, this patient has a negative HIV test.
Image Description:

Photograph of the left anterior thigh of a young girl

Several skin-colored papules with central umbilication can be seen.

These features are characteristic of molluscum contagiosum.

B) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma accounts for > 80% of cases of vulvar cancer. However, this condition typically manifests with ulcerating masses and leukoplakia, not exophytic and cauliflower-like masses.
Image Description:

The labia minora and majora are difficult to identify due to the destructive, ulcerative, and exophytic growth of the tumor. The affected region shows a livid discoloration with bloody lesions.

These findings are suggestive of a squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva. Diagnosis was confirmed by biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Genital herpes is mainly caused by HSV-2 and can manifest with skin lesions in the anogenital region. However, the lesions of genital herpes are typically painful, erythematous papules and fluid-filled vesicles that ulcerate, not exophytic and cauliflower-like masses. Genital herpes also often results in painful lymphadenopathy in the groin area, which this patient does not have.
Image Description:

Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patient

Fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.

These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

D) CORRECT:

Condylomata acuminata (anogenital warts) are caused by sexually transmitted human papillomavirus types 6 and 11 in most cases. The lesions typically manifest on the vulva, penis, or perianal region and are often exophytic and cauliflower-like, although they can also have a flat or pedunculated appearance. Condylomata acuminata are usually asymptomatic but may cause bleeding and be painful and/or pruritic. There are several treatment options, including local cytostatic treatment (e.g., trichloroacetic acid, podofilox), immune response modifiers (e.g., imiquimod), cryotherapy, and, for more severe cases, curettage, laser surgery, and electrocoagulation. The rate of recurrence is high.

E) INCORRECT:

Bowenoid papulosis is a rare, premalignant, focal epidermal dysplasia caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection (most commonly HPV type 16). This condition typically manifests as multiple, flat, red-brown pigmented papules on the external genitals, not exophytic and cauliflower-like masses.
Image Description:

Labia majora of an immunocompetent patient with an infiltrative and eroded tumor (arrow)

Multiple flat and hyperpigmented patches are disseminated over the patient's upper labia majora.

These patches suggest Bowenoid papulosis, caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.

F) INCORRECT:

Condylomata lata are painless skin lesions in the anogenital region that occur in secondary syphilis. However, condylomata lata are typically broad-based, smooth, papular erosions, not exophytic, and cauliflower-like masses. Moreover, secondary syphilis typically causes generalized lymphadenopathy and constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue), which this patient does not have.
Image Description:

Broad-based papular erosions are visible around this patient's anus.

Clustering around the anus and the typical appearance are suggestive of condylomata lata, a sign of secondary syphilis.

G) INCORRECT:

Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown origin that classically manifests with pruritic, planar (flat-topped), polygonal, purple papules, and plaques (the 6 Ps of lichen planus) in individuals 30–60 years of age. This condition usually involves the extremities but may also affect the genitals. Although this patient's lesions are mildly pruritic, they do not have the classic morphologic features of lichen planus. Moreover, genital lichen planus typically leads to dyspareunia.
questions.hint: The lesions would turn white upon the application of dilute acetic acid.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of skin bumps on her right hand. Her mother took her to the doctor when she first noticed them 2 years ago. No treatment was given at that time and the doctor reassured her that they would resolve on their own. However, the patient is now being made fun of at school because of the lesions on her hand, and her mother is worried that the lesions or treatment might result in permanent scarring. The patient has otherwise been well and her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears scared. A photograph of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical administration of fluorouracil (FU) can be used in patients with common warts who have not responded to first-line treatment. However, topical FU is associated with multiple side effects (e.g., erythema, dryness, burning sensation), and its safety and effectiveness have not been established for pediatric use, making a different intervention more appropriate for this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulsed dye laser therapy is a second-line treatment option for patients with common warts. Given the high cost, low availability, and side effects of the procedure (e.g., skin discoloration, scarring, pain), pulsed dye laser therapy is reserved for patients who have not responded to first-line therapy. This patient has not yet received any treatment; therefore, another treatment option is indicated at this point.

C) INCORRECT:

Intralesional bleomycin injection may be indicated for patients with common warts that are refractory to first-line treatment. However, this injection is not recommended for immunosuppressed individuals, pregnant women, or children because of the risk of systemic absorption of bleomycin (a chemotherapeutic agent).

D) CORRECT:

Topical salicylic acid is one of the first-line treatment options for the management of common warts in patients who present with associated pain, functional impairment, or discomfort. The benefits of this treatment option include high efficacy and availability, low cost, painless application, and minimal side effects, all of which make topical salicylic acid a safe option for wart removal in pediatric patients. Topical salicylic acid can also be combined with other first-line treatment options, such as cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen, for a faster and more effective therapeutic response.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical excision (e.g., curettage) is a second-line treatment option for the management of common warts. This option is reserved for patients who have not responded to first-line therapy or who request the immediate removal of warts. However, surgery is associated with an increased risk of scarring, infection, and wart recurrence, which limits its use in clinical practice.
questions.hint: This patient's partially confluent, hyperkeratotic papules with a rough surface are consistent with common warts, which are caused by human papillomavirus.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of bleeding from a growth in the rectal area. She has also had mild perianal itching and tenderness for the past 2 months. She tried empiric treatment with over-the-counter podofilox solution but reports that “the bumps never completely disappeared.” Her medical history is remarkable for HIV infection and hypertension. She has not been sexually active since her husband died 1 year ago. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Her diet consists mostly of fast food and soft drinks. Current medications include antiretroviral therapy and lisinopril. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the perianal area shows a 3-cm friable, exophytic mass. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intralesional interferon is an immune-mediating therapy that can be used for refractory anogenital warts. It is typically given in conjunction with cytodestructive therapies (e.g., 5-fluorouracil) and/or surgical therapies (e.g., cryoablation). However, a different next step in management is more appropriate prior to the continued treatment of refractory anogenital warts.

B) INCORRECT:

Cryoablation is a surgical therapy and one of the first-line treatment options for anogenital warts. However, a different next step in management is more appropriate prior to the continued treatment of refractory anogenital warts.

C) INCORRECT:

Chemoradiotherapy (with fluorouracil, mitomycin, and radiation therapy) is the treatment of choice for squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal. Although malignant degeneration of anogenital warts is more common in immunocompromised patients, and a history of refractory anogenital warts should raise concern for malignancy, the diagnosis should be confirmed prior to initiating treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Anogenital warts turn white upon application of acetic acid. This is, however, a nonspecific finding that is also seen in other conditions such as psoriasis, candidiasis, and lichen planus. Therefore, the application of acetic acid is not recommended in the evaluation of patients with suspected refractory anogenital warts.

E) CORRECT:

A shave biopsy can confirm the diagnosis of anogenital warts and evaluate for malignancy, which is associated with high-risk human papillomavirus types. Findings that should raise concern for malignancy and are indications for biopsy include immunosuppression (e.g., HIV infection), insufficient response to treatment, and atypical features (e.g., induration, bleeding, pigmentation, ulceration), all of which are seen here. Evaluation with anoscopy should also be considered to evaluate for involvement within the anal canal.

Recurrence and refractory disease are common in patients with anogenital warts, especially in individuals with immunosuppression. Treatments for anogenital warts include cytodestructive therapies (e.g., trichloroacetic acid), immune-mediated therapies (e.g., imiquimod), and surgical therapies (e.g., cryoablation, excision).
questions.hint: This patient's history and examination findings are consistent with refractory anogenital warts.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old woman presents for evaluation, reporting a “swollen gland” of 2 months’ duration. She denies any associated symptoms. She reports drinking one glass of wine per week and has never smoked.
Physical examination reveals a left-sided upper cervical lymph node measuring 3.5 cm with mild overlying erythema and a right-sided cervical lymph node measuring 1.5 cm. Her tongue is normal, but her left tonsil is slightly enlarged. Her condition has not changed since she completed a 10-day course of amoxicillin-clavulanate.
A CT scan reveals no other abnormalities. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the left cervical lymph node confirms a diagnosis of squamous-cell carcinoma.
Which one of the following factors is most likely to have contributed to this patient’s oropharyngeal cancer?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Epstein-Barr virus infection is associated with Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma but not with oropharyngeal cancers.

B) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis C virus infection is not associated with an increased risk for head and neck cancers.

C) INCORRECT:

Colonization with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus is not associated with an increased risk for head and neck cancers.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease can lead to Barrett esophagus (esophageal metaplasia), which is a risk factor for adenocarcinoma of the esophagus but not for squamous-cell carcinoma of the head and neck.

E) CORRECT:

Squamous-cell carcinomas of the head and neck are most common in older men who have a substantial history of cigarette smoking and alcohol use. In contrast, squamous-cell carcinomas of the oropharynx (for example, at the base of the tongue or on the tonsils) are being diagnosed more frequently in younger patients who do not smoke or drink. Epidemiologic and molecular studies have shown that, similar to cervical cancer, these cancers are associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, particularly of the HPV-16 subtype. HPV-associated squamous-cell carcinomas tend to manifest with small primary tumors and with large, bulky, and occasionally cystic lymph nodes. Interestingly, HPV-associated tumors carry a better prognosis than non-HPV-associated tumors.

Key learning point: Squamous-cell carcinoma of the oropharynx in a person who has never smoked is most often associated with human papillomavirus infection.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old female marathon runner presents with a lesion on the heel of her right foot that has been growing larger for the past 6 months and is moderately painful when she exercises. She is otherwise healthy.
Examination reveals a 1-cm rough plaque on the heel of her right foot (figure). When the skin is examined with a magnifying glass, tiny punctate hemorrhages seem embedded in the plaque, with distortion of the normal skin lines. The rest of the patient’s skin examination is normal.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The most likely diagnosis in this patient is a plantar wart (verruca plantaris). Plantar warts are caused by specific strains of the human papillomavirus and typically manifest as endophytic verrucous plaques on the plantar surface of the foot, with a characteristic dry, rough surface that interrupts the normal skin lines and pinpoint hemorrhagic macules representing thrombosed capillaries. Plantar warts are sometimes symptomatic, causing discomfort during ambulation.

Although warts may resolve spontaneously, treatment is reasonable if the wart is causing symptoms, if there is frequent trauma to the site of the wart, or if the wart is in a genital or peri-orificial location. Single treatment of warts has modest therapeutic benefit; therefore, combination treatment and repeat treatments are often necessary.

There are two fundamental strategies for treating warts:
• Destructive methods, which include paring of the wart, liquid nitrogen/cryosurgery, laser therapy, topical salicylic acid, fluorouracil cream, cantharidin, topical retinoid creams, intralesional bleomycin or other chemotherapy, and surgical excision.
• Immunotherapy methods, which include intralesional Candida antigen, imiquimod cream, and contact sensitization.

Office-based paring followed by liquid nitrogen therapy and in-home salicylic acid treatment between office visits is a common first-line approach to treating plantar warts.

Key learning point: First-line therapy for a symptomatic plantar wart is cryotherapy or salicylic acid.

B) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin gel (or in some cases oral erythromycin) is used to treat a distinct, common rash on the foot called pitted keratolysis, which is caused by bacterial infection. The hallmark of this rash is plantar skin maceration with sharply demarcated vermiform pits and a strong, fruity odor.

C) INCORRECT:

Orthotics might be appropriate for a long-distance runner with a callus. However, calluses are readily distinguishable from plantar warts because they accentuate, rather than replace, normal skin lines over bony pressure points. Calluses are caused by repetitive trauma, which induces protective hyperkeratosis that preserves the skin lines and accentuates normal sole anatomy. Plantar warts interrupt the normal skin lines on the foot, as shown in the figure in this case. In addition, the lesion in this case is not in an area common to calluses.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical removal is occasionally considered for warts at other sites but is avoided for plantar warts because of the risk of scars, which can be chronically painful at this site.

E) INCORRECT:

Econazole cream would be an excellent choice for treatment of tinea pedis, a superficial fungal infection, but this patient’s presentation is not consistent with that diagnosis. Tinea pedis is an erythematous scaly eruption on the plantar aspect of the foot, often involving the interdigital webspaces with maceration. This diagnosis can be confirmed by performing microscopic analysis of skin scrapings in 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution, thereby revealing branching hyphal elements. Long-standing tinea pedis may result in concomitant toenail infection, marked by yellow, dystrophic nails with subungual hyperkeratosis.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old girl with a history of mild, well-controlled intermittent asthma arrives for a routine well-child visit. She is in the fifth grade and is excelling in school. She has not yet reached menarche. Other than receiving an annual seasonal influenza vaccine last year as well as Covid-19 vaccines, she has not received any vaccines since before kindergarten entry.
Which one of the following sets of vaccines is appropriate for this girl to receive within the next year?

choices.text: Human papillomavirus, influenza, and pneumococcal conjugate vaccines
Influenza, tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis, and meningococcal conjugate vaccines
Human papillomavirus, tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis, influenza, and meningococcal conjugate vaccines

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The pneumococcal conjugate vaccine is a four-dose series routinely completed before 15 months of age.

B) INCORRECT:

The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recommends that all boys and girls receive HPV vaccination starting at 11 or 12 years of age, but vaccination can be started as early as 9 years of age. Therefore, an 11-year-old girl is eligible for four vaccines in all: HPV, Tdap, meningococcal conjugate, and influenza, barring clear contraindications.

C) INCORRECT:

The varicella-zoster vaccine is a two-dose series administered at age 12 to 15 months and again at age 4 to 6 years.

D) INCORRECT:

The varicella-zoster vaccine is a two-dose series administered at age 12 to 15 months and again at age 4 to 6 years. Prophylaxis against influenza is recommended yearly.

E) CORRECT:

Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) are the most common sexually transmitted infections in the United States, and more than 40 strains of the virus exist. The recently approved 9-valent HPV recombinant vaccine (9vHPV) provides immunologic protection against strains 6 and 11 (which contribute to the formation of genital warts), strains 16 and 18 (which contribute to the development of vulvar, cervical, anal, and penile cancers), and strains 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58 (which are also oncogenic).

The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recommends that all boys and girls receive HPV vaccination starting at 11 or 12 years of age, but vaccination can be started as early as 9 years of age. Vaccination is also recommended for females aged 13 through 26 years and males aged 13 through 21 years who have not been vaccinated or who have not received all three doses of an HPV vaccine. If the first HPV vaccine is administered before a child's 15th birthday, two doses, separated by 6 to 12 months, are recommended. If the vaccine is initiated after the 15th birthday, three doses are required, with the second and third doses administered 1 to 2 months and 6 months after the first dose.

The only contraindications to HPV vaccine administration are pregnancy, current severe illness, yeast allergy, and a previous anaphylactic reaction to HPV vaccination. Previous sexual activity, known HPV infection, HIV infection, and medication-induced immunosuppression are not contraindications to HPV vaccination.

Syncope has been documented following receipt of the HPV vaccine; therefore, the AAP recommends that patients lie down for 15 minutes after receipt of the vaccine.

The first dose of the meningococcal conjugate vaccine is recommended at 11 years of age, with a booster at 16 years. Prophylaxis against influenza is recommended yearly. A dose of tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap) is recommended between 11 and 12 years of age. Therefore, an 11-year-old girl is eligible for four vaccines in all: HPV, Tdap, meningococcal conjugate, and influenza, barring clear contraindications.

Key learning point: The 9-valent human papillomavirus recombinant vaccine should be routinely recommended to all boys and girls at the ages of 11 or 12 years but can be administered as early as 9 years of age.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl presents for evaluation of skin lesions that have slowly increased in number during the past month. The lesions are not painful, but the girl frequently picks at them. She has no significant medical history, and her immunizations are up to date.
Skin examination reveals several 3- to 5-mm flesh-colored papules with a rough texture predominantly on the patient's feet and hands with a larger lesion on the distal end of her thumb (figure).
What is the most appropriate first-line therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Podophyllotoxin is effective on mucosal surfaces and is therefore used to treat genital warts. Few data support its use for nongenital warts.

B) INCORRECT:

Imiquimod cream is indicated for genital, not common, warts. It is also used to treat actinic keratosis (scaly hyperkeratotic papules or patches in sun-exposed areas, primarily in adults, that represent precursor lesions to squamous-cell carcinoma) and superficial basal-cell carcinoma (red, pink, or flesh-colored pearly papules, ulcerated lesions, or scar-like lesions in sun-exposed areas, primarily in adults or in children with basal-cell nevus syndrome).

C) INCORRECT:

The HPV vaccine prevents infection with the HPV serotypes implicated in anogenital warts and cervical cancer (6, 11, 16, and 18) but not the serotypes that cause common warts (cutaneous warts, of the hands and feet). In addition, the HPV vaccine is approved for use starting at age 9 and would not be appropriate in this young child.

D) CORRECT:

Common warts (verruca vulgaris) appear as flesh-colored, wide-based papules with punctate black discolorations (dilated vessels) and a grainy (verrucous) texture. They are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV), which is transmitted through skin-to-skin contact or infected fomites. The HPV serotypes that cause common warts are distinct from those that cause genital warts.

About two-thirds of common warts resolve on their own without any therapy. There are many available therapies; however, pooled data from six randomized controlled trials showed cure rates of 75% with salicylic acid versus 48% with placebo. There was no clear evidence to suggest that other therapies, such as cryotherapy, had higher cure rates or fewer adverse effects than salicylic acid. Salicylic acid is a particularly good first-line option for children because it is not painful; however, it does often require at least 3 months of daily use.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first-line therapy for common warts is topical salicylic acid.

E) INCORRECT:

There is no clear evidence to suggest that other therapies, such as cryotherapy, had higher cure rates or fewer adverse effects than salicylic acid.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl presents with a lesion on the heel of her right foot that has been growing larger for the past 6 months and is moderately painful when she runs and plays soccer. She is otherwise healthy.
Examination reveals a 1-cm rough plaque on the heel of her right foot (figure). When the skin is examined with a magnifying glass, tiny punctate hemorrhages seem embedded in the plaque. The rest of the patient’s skin examination is normal.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Econazole cream would be an excellent choice for treatment of tinea pedis, a superficial fungal infection, but this patient’s presentation is not consistent with that diagnosis. Tinea pedis is an erythematous scaly eruption on the plantar aspect of the foot, often involving the interdigital webspaces with maceration. This diagnosis can be confirmed by performing microscopic analysis of skin scrapings in 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution, thereby revealing branching hyphal elements. Long-standing tinea pedis may result in concomitant toenail infection, marked by yellow, dystrophic nails with subungual hyperkeratosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Orthotics might be appropriate for athletes with a callus. However, calluses are readily distinguishable from plantar warts because they accentuate, rather than replace, normal skin lines over bony pressure points. Calluses are caused by repetitive trauma, which induces protective hyperkeratosis that preserves the skin lines and accentuates normal sole anatomy. Plantar warts interrupt the normal skin lines on the foot, as shown in the figure in this case. In addition, the lesion in this case is not in an area common to calluses.

C) INCORRECT:

Imiquimod cream, whose primary indication is the treatment of genital warts, is not a highly effective treatment for warts in nonmucosal sites.

D) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin gel (or in some cases oral erythromycin) is used to treat a distinct, common rash on the foot called pitted keratolysis, which is caused by bacterial infection. The hallmark of this rash is plantar skin maceration with sharply demarcated vermiform pits and a strong, fruity odor.

E) CORRECT:

The most likely diagnosis in this patient is a plantar wart (verruca plantaris). Plantar warts are caused by specific strains of the human papillomavirus and typically manifest as endophytic or exophytic verrucous plaques on the plantar surface of the foot, with a characteristic dry, rough surface that interrupts the normal skin lines and pinpoint hemorrhagic macules representing thrombosed capillaries. Plantar warts are sometimes symptomatic, causing discomfort during ambulation.

Although warts may resolve spontaneously, treatment is reasonable if the wart is causing symptoms, if there is frequent trauma to the site of the wart, or if the wart is in a sensitive location. Single treatment of warts has modest therapeutic benefit; therefore, combination treatment and repeat treatments are often necessary.

There are two fundamental strategies for treating warts:

• Destructive methods, which include paring of the wart, liquid nitrogen/cryosurgery, laser therapy, topical salicylic acid, fluorouracil cream, cantharidin, topical retinoid creams, intralesional bleomycin or other chemotherapy, and surgical excision. Of note, surgical excision is not recommended as the wart often recurs due to microscopic extension beyond the visible portion.
• Immunotherapy methods, which include intralesional Candida antigen, imiquimod cream, and contact sensitization.

Office-based paring followed by liquid nitrogen therapy and in-home salicylic acid treatment between office visits is a common first-line approach to treating plantar warts. Because liquid nitrogen can be a painful treatment, some children will opt for salicylic acid, which is slower but painless. It is important to allow a child who is 8 years or older to participate in the treatment decision. Cryotherapy and other painful therapies should be deferred in younger patients to prevent psychological trauma and ongoing fear of doctors.

Key learning point: First-line therapy for a symptomatic plantar wart is cryotherapy or salicylic acid.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the office because of a 2-week history of genital lesions. She has no history of serious illness. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows multiple hyperkeratotic exophytic papules over the vulva. The lesions turn white on application of 3% acetic acid. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although condom use may help reduce the risk of HPV transmission, studies have shown that contact with uncovered areas still allows for HPV transmission. Condom use is therefore not the best option for preventing this patient's condition.

B) INCORRECT:

HIV can present with genital lesions in a sexually active individual. Molluscum contagiosum, which is a common genital lesion in adults associated with HIV, could present with a nontender, exophytic papule on the genitalia. However, these lesions would have a characteristic hemispherical, umbilicated appearance, and they would not turn white on application of 3% acetic acid. Moreover, there are no other features in this patient that suggest immunocompromise, which is typical of HIV.

C) INCORRECT:

Spermicidal foams and gels are means of contraception with medium efficacy and may be used by sexually active individuals who do not intend to get pregnant. However, they do not provide any protection against sexually transmitted infections, such as the one in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Famciclovir is used for the treatment and prophylaxis of genital herpes caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV-1 or HSV-2). A case of genital herpes could present with multiple raised lesions over the vulva. However, the lesions would be vesicular or ulcerative, very painful, and associated with systemic features (like fever, lymphadenopathy, etc.), which are not seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patient

Fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.

These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with condylomata acuminata, which are genital warts caused by HPV. HPV vaccines are recommended by the CDC to all persons aged 9–26 years and are most effective before exposure to HPV via sexual activity; they are routinely administered at 11–12 years of age. The tetravalent and 9-valent vaccines provide ∼ 99% coverage against the types of HPV most commonly implicated in genital warts (types 6 and 11) and in cervical cancer (especially types 16 and 18) for at least 10 years after vaccination (likely longer, but data is only available for that time period). Given this patient's sexual history, HPV vaccine would most likely have prevented this condition.

Some older HPV vaccines (e.g., Cervarix®) do not cover the types of HPV associated with genital warts (types 6 and 11) and only protect against cervical cancer.
Image Description:

Photograph of the perianal region of a child with HIV (image rotated: gluteal cleft runs from upper right to lower left of image)

Multiple flesh-colored papules with a folded irregular surface have formed a plaque in the perianal region.

Immunodeficiency (e.g., due to HIV infection) increases both the risk of HPV infection becoming symptomatic (in this case with anogenital warts) and the severity of symptoms
questions.hint: In a sexually active adolescent, the presence of multiple hyperkeratotic exophytic papules indicates human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with painless lesions on the vulva that she first noticed 2 days ago. She does not have any urinary symptoms. She is sexually active with multiple partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Examination shows clusters of several 3- to 5-mm raised lesions with a rough texture on the vulva. The lesions turn white after application of a dilute acetic acid solution. An HIV test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Benzathine penicillin is indicated for the treatment of syphilis, for which this patient's sexual activity puts her at risk. Secondary syphilis may manifest with condylomata lata. However, condylomata lata are nonverrucous, flat-topped papules, and would not change color upon application of acetic acid.
Image Description:

Broad-based papular erosions are visible around this patient's anus.

Clustering around the anus and the typical appearance are suggestive of condylomata lata, a sign of secondary syphilis.

B) CORRECT:

Cryotherapy, curettage, laser surgery, and electrocoagulation are all appropriate destructive treatment options for condylomata acuminata, especially in cases involving numerous warts. Pharmacotherapy options include local cytostatic treatment (e.g., trichloroacetic acid, podofilox) and immune response modifiers (e.g., imiquimod). The rate of recurrence is high.
Image Description:

Multiple exophytic, cauliflower-like, confluent, skin-colored papules are visible in the perianal region.

C) INCORRECT:

Mometasone is a steroid indicated for the treatment of lichen planus, a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown origin. Typical lichen planus lesions are pruritic, planar, polygonal, purple papules and plaques (the 6 Ps of lichen planus), unlike this patient's lesions. This condition usually involves flexural surfaces of the extremities but can also affect the genitalia. Moreover, lesions do not change color upon application of acetic acid.
Image Description:

Scattered, partially coalescent violaceous papules, macules, and plaques are visible on the shins.

D) INCORRECT:

Radiotherapy may be indicated for vulva cancer, which is typically a slow-growing squamous cell carcinoma. Vulvar cancer can manifest with cauliflower-like growths, but the sudden onset and lack of other features (e.g., pruritus, leukoplakia, lymphadenopathy, or bleeding ulcerations) make vulvar cancer unlikely.
Image Description:

The labia minora and majora are difficult to identify due to the destructive, ulcerative, and exophytic growth of the tumor. The affected region shows a livid discoloration with bloody lesions.

These findings are suggestive of a squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva. Diagnosis was confirmed by biopsy.

E) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used to treat genital herpes, which typically manifests with painful, erosive vesicles that are accompanied by painful lymphadenopathy in the groin area. This patient does not have lymphadenopathy or tender vesicles, making genital herpes unlikely.
Image Description:

Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patient

Fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.

These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.
questions.hint: Clusters of nonpainful raised, rough-textured genital lesions that whiten after application of acetic acid suggests condylomata acuminata, which is caused by human papillomavirus (HPV).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the office because of an 8-month history of multiple painless bumps on the vulva. The bumps are mildly itchy; one of the bumps has bled before when she tried to pull on it. She denies dyspareunia. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the genital area is shown. An HIV test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum (MC) is a localized infection of the skin caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus. MC most commonly affects young children but can manifest in adults with nontender lesions in the genital region. However, the lesions of MC are typically discrete, pearly, dome-shaped, and smooth, with central umbilication; MC does not cause exophytic and cauliflower-like masses. Although large, widespread lesions can develop in individuals who are immunocompromised, this patient has a negative HIV test.
Image Description:

Photograph of the left anterior thigh of a young girl

Several skin-colored papules with central umbilication can be seen.

These features are characteristic of molluscum contagiosum.

B) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma accounts for > 80% of cases of vulvar cancer. However, this condition typically manifests with ulcerating masses and leukoplakia, not exophytic and cauliflower-like masses.
Image Description:

The labia minora and majora are difficult to identify due to the destructive, ulcerative, and exophytic growth of the tumor. The affected region shows a livid discoloration with bloody lesions.

These findings are suggestive of a squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva. Diagnosis was confirmed by biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Genital herpes is mainly caused by HSV-2 and can manifest with skin lesions in the anogenital region. However, the lesions of genital herpes are typically painful, erythematous papules and fluid-filled vesicles that ulcerate, not exophytic and cauliflower-like masses. Genital herpes also often results in painful lymphadenopathy in the groin area, which this patient does not have.
Image Description:

Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patient

Fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.

These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

D) CORRECT:

Condylomata acuminata (anogenital warts) are caused by sexually transmitted human papillomavirus types 6 and 11 in most cases. The lesions typically manifest on the vulva, penis, or perianal region and are often exophytic and cauliflower-like, although they can also have a flat or pedunculated appearance. Condylomata acuminata are usually asymptomatic but may cause bleeding and be painful and/or pruritic. There are several treatment options, including local cytostatic treatment (e.g., trichloroacetic acid, podofilox), immune response modifiers (e.g., imiquimod), cryotherapy, and, for more severe cases, curettage, laser surgery, and electrocoagulation. The rate of recurrence is high.

E) INCORRECT:

Condylomata lata are painless skin lesions in the anogenital region that occur in secondary syphilis. However, condylomata lata are typically broad-based, smooth, papular erosions, not exophytic, and cauliflower-like masses. Moreover, secondary syphilis typically causes generalized lymphadenopathy and constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue), which this patient does not have.
Image Description:

Broad-based papular erosions are visible around this patient's anus.

Clustering around the anus and the typical appearance are suggestive of condylomata lata, a sign of secondary syphilis.
questions.hint: The lesions would turn white upon the application of dilute acetic acid.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the office because of growths around her anus that developed over the past 4 weeks. They are not painful and she does not have blood in her stool. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows nontender, irregular, hyperkeratotic sessile lesions in the perianal area around 4–7 mm in diameter. There is no lymphadenopathy. The application of a dilute solution of acetic acid turns the lesions white. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the lesions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The molluscum contagiosum (MC) virus is a DNA poxvirus that most commonly affects young children. It also affects adults, particularly those who are immunocompromised (e.g., due to HIV infection, chemotherapy, or extensive corticosteroid therapy). MC is transmitted through direct skin contact, autoinoculation, or fomites. Lesions are typically nontender and located on the face, trunk, and extremities. Sexually transmitted MC can cause lesions in the groin, lower abdomen, and genitals. In contrast to this patient's skin lesions, characteristic MC lesions are pearly, flesh-colored, dome-shaped, and smooth with a central umbilication.
Image Description:

Photograph of the abdomen and groin of a young child

Single and grouped skin-colored papules with central umbilication can be seen.

These features are consistent with the diagnosis of molluscum contagiosum.

B) INCORRECT:

T. pallidum is the pathogen responsible for syphilis. Secondary syphilis can manifest with condyloma lata, which are painless skin lesions in the anogenital region. However, condylomata lata are typically broad-based, smooth, papular erosions, not exophytic, and cauliflower-like masses. Moreover, secondary syphilis typically causes generalized lymphadenopathy and constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue), which this patient does not have. Finally, acetic acid would not turn syphilitic lesions white.
Image Description:

Broad-based papular erosions are visible around this patient's anus.

Clustering around the anus and the typical appearance are suggestive of condylomata lata, a sign of secondary syphilis.

C) INCORRECT:

Malignant transformation of squamous cells (i.e., SCC) is the underlying pathomechanism in the majority of patients with anal cancer. Symptoms consistent with SCC of the anus include rectal bleeding, itching, pain, lymphadenopathy, and/or anal discharge. Rather than multiple smaller growths around the anus, a larger, solitary mass in the anal canal would be more likely. If this patient had rectal bleeding or other concerning symptoms, benign causes (e.g., hemorrhoids, anal fissure, and warts) would be investigated first.
Image Description:

A friable, exophytic mass is visible at the anal orifice.

These features suggest an anal cancer.

D) CORRECT:

HPV strains 6 and 11 cause 90% of genital warts, or condylomata acuminata. These lesions are cauliflower-like in their appearance, with a flat, papular, or pedunculated shape, and are commonly found on the mucosa or along the epithelium of the anogenital tract. They are usually asymptomatic but may be painful or pruritic in some cases. Application of 3–5% acetic acid will turn the lesion white, though this test has poor specificity for warts since polyps or leukoplakia can also appear white. Risk factors for HPV include multiple sexual partners and unprotected sexual intercourse.
Image Description:

Multiple exophytic, cauliflower-like, confluent, skin-colored papules are visible in the perianal region.

E) INCORRECT:

Infection with the oncogenic high-risk HPV strains (especially HPV-16 and HPV-18) may lead to precancerous and cancerous lesions. These high-risk strains account for more than 70% of cervical cancers and can also cause genital, oral, and oropharyngeal squamous cell cancers. However, HPV-18 is not responsible for anogenital warts.
questions.hint: The cauliflower-like growths in the perianal area may be treated with cryotherapy or, in more severe cases, curettage, laser surgery, or electrocoagulation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the office because of skin lesions on and around his anus. The lesions are not painful, and he does not have any urinary complaints. He is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He appears healthy. A photograph of the perianal region is shown. The lesions turn white after application of a dilute acetic acid solution. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An HIV test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used to treat genital herpes, which typically manifests with painful, erosive vesicles that are accompanied by painful lymphadenopathy in the groin area. This patient does not have lymphadenopathy or tender vesicles, making genital herpes unlikely.
Image Description:

Penile shaft and glans

Two ulcerated blisters with erythematous margins are visible proximal to the corona of the glans.

B) INCORRECT:

Mometasone is a steroid indicated for the treatment of lichen planus, a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown origin. Typical lichen planus lesions are pruritic, planar, polygonal, purple papules and plaques (the 6 Ps of lichen planus), unlike this patient's verrucous papules. This condition usually involves flexural surfaces of the extremities but can also affect the genitalia. Moreover, lesions do not change color upon application of acetic acid.
Image Description:

Lacelike papular lines are visible on the penis, extending from the glans to the shaft.

This feature is suggestive of Wickham striae, a typical finding in Lichen planus.

C) INCORRECT:

Radiotherapy may be indicated for anal cancer, which is typically a slow-growing squamous cell carcinoma. Anal cancer can manifest with cauliflower-like growths, but the lack of other features (e.g., pruritus, leukoplakia, lymphadenopathy, bleeding ulcerations) makes anal cancer unlikely in this patient. However, in addition to the HPV types that cause condylomata acuminata (6 and 11), this patient may be coinfected with high-risk HPV subtypes (especially 16 and 18), which increases his risk of developing anal cancer.
Image Description:

Patient in the lithotomy position

An exophytic tumor of the anal margin is visible, located from approximately 12 to 7 o'clock in the lithotomy position. There are also multiple round skin lesions that are approx. 15 mm in diameter, with most on the right buttock bordering the lower back.

D) INCORRECT:

Benzathine penicillin is indicated for the treatment of syphilis, for which this patient's sexual activity puts him at risk. Secondary syphilis can manifest with condylomata lata. However, lesions of condylomata lata are nonverrucous, flat-topped papules that do not change color upon application of acetic acid.
Image Description:

Broad-based papular erosions are visible around this patient's anus.

Clustering around the anus and the typical appearance are suggestive of condylomata lata, a sign of secondary syphilis.

E) CORRECT:

Curettage, cryotherapy, laser surgery, and electrocoagulation are all appropriate destructive treatment options for condylomata acuminata, especially in cases involving numerous warts. Pharmacotherapy options include local cytostatic treatment (e.g., podofilox, trichloroacetic acid) and immune response modifiers (e.g., imiquimod). The rate of recurrence is high.
questions.hint: Clusters of nontender, verrucous anogenital papules that whiten after application of acetic acid are consistent with condylomata acuminata, which is caused by human papillomavirus (HPV).

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 2-month history of pain with defecation, anal itching, and blood in the stool. Over the past month, she has also had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss. She has a history of irritable bowel syndrome, HIV infection, and human papillomavirus infection. Current medications include a combined antiretroviral treatment regimen and an oral contraceptive. She is sexually active with one male partner. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 66/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg. Examination of the perianal region shows no abnormalities. Digital rectal examination shows a tender mass and bright red blood in the anal canal. Anoscopy shows an exophytic, ulcerated, 2.5-cm mass that is located just above the anocutaneous line and below the dentate line. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A fibroepithelial polyp of the anus can manifest as an exophytic lesion in the perianal region. However, patients are usually asymptomatic. Moreover, fibroepithelial polyps of the anus arise from anal columns at the dentate line rather than near the anocutaneous line.

B) INCORRECT:

Internal hemorrhoids can manifest with anal pruritus, hematochezia, and a palpable mass on digital rectal examination. Furthermore, in a patient with irritable bowel syndrome, constipation is a common feature and a risk factor for developing hemorrhoids. However, internal hemorrhoids more commonly appear as dilated, purple or blue veins on anoscopy rather than an exophytic ulcerated mass, and, because they arise from the superior hemorrhoidal plexus, they are located above the dentate line rather than the anocutaneous line. Moreover, defecation is usually painless and weight loss is not expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Condylomata acuminata of the anus is caused by HPV infection, which this patient has a history of, and can manifest as an exophytic lesion. However, although condylomata acuminata are pruritic, tender, and friable in a small percentage of cases, they are more commonly asymptomatic; weight loss is not expected. Moreover, when present in the anal canal, condylomata acuminata usually appear as small papules rather than large, ulcerated lesions.

D) INCORRECT:

Paget disease of the anus can manifest with anal pruritus, pain with defecation, and hematochezia, all of which are seen here. However, besides being extremely rare, this condition usually manifests as well-demarcated erythematous plaques or patches with a white scale rather than a single ulcerated, exophytic lesion.

E) CORRECT:

A history of hematochezia, anal pruritus, painful defecation, and weight loss in a patient with an exophytic, friable, ulcerated mass above the anal verge is suggestive of anal canal cancer. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common histological type of anal canal cancer and typically arises below the dentate line (see “Characteristics of the anal canal above and below the dentate line” table). Patients must undergo a biopsy of the tumor to confirm the diagnosis. Women diagnosed with anal canal squamous cell carcinoma should also undergo a gynecological examination for cervical cancer screening.
questions.hint: A history of immunodeficiency (e.g., caused by HIV infection) and prior human papillomavirus (HPV) infection are major risk factors for this condition.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother because of skin bumps on her right hand. Her mother took her to the doctor when she first noticed them 2 years ago. No treatment was given at that time and the doctor reassured her that they would resolve on their own. However, the patient is now being made fun of at school because of the lesions on her hand, and her mother is worried that the lesions or treatment might result in permanent scarring. The patient has otherwise been well and her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears scared. A photograph of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical administration of fluorouracil (FU) can be used in patients with common warts who have not responded to first-line treatment. However, topical FU is associated with multiple side effects (e.g., erythema, dryness, burning sensation), and its safety and effectiveness have not been established for pediatric use, making a different intervention more appropriate for this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulsed dye laser therapy is a second-line treatment option for patients with common warts. Given the high cost, low availability, and side effects of the procedure (e.g., skin discoloration, scarring, pain), pulsed dye laser therapy is reserved for patients who have not responded to first-line therapy. This patient has not yet received any treatment; therefore, another treatment option is indicated at this point.

C) INCORRECT:

Intralesional bleomycin injection may be indicated for patients with common warts that are refractory to first-line treatment. However, this injection is not recommended for immunosuppressed individuals, pregnant women, or children because of the risk of systemic absorption of bleomycin (a chemotherapeutic agent).

D) CORRECT:

Topical salicylic acid is one of the first-line treatment options for the management of common warts in patients who present with associated pain, functional impairment, or discomfort. The benefits of this treatment option include high efficacy and availability, low cost, painless application, and minimal side effects, all of which make topical salicylic acid a safe option for wart removal in pediatric patients. Topical salicylic acid can also be combined with other first-line treatment options, such as cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen, for a faster and more effective therapeutic response.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical excision (e.g., curettage) is a second-line treatment option for the management of common warts. This option is reserved for patients who have not responded to first-line therapy or who request the immediate removal of warts. However, surgery is associated with an increased risk of scarring, infection, and wart recurrence, which limits its use in clinical practice.
questions.hint: This patient's partially confluent, hyperkeratotic papules with a rough surface are consistent with common warts, which are caused by human papillomavirus.

questions.text: You are seeing a 7-year-old girl who is brought to your clinic by her mother because of skin bumps on her right hand. The lesions were first noticed 2 years ago, and at that time, no treatment was given as her previous physician reassured the family that they would resolve spontaneously. The patient is now experiencing teasing at school due to the lesions, and her mother is concerned about the possibility of permanent scarring from the lesions or their treatment. The patient has been otherwise well and her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears scared. A photograph of the lesions is provided. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A) INCORRECT:

Surgical excision (e.g., curettage) is a second-line treatment option for the management of common warts. This option is reserved for patients who have not responded to first-line therapy or who request the immediate removal of warts. However, surgery is associated with an increased risk of scarring, infection, and wart recurrence, which limits its use in clinical practice.
